repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Currently there is no way for `vim.pack` to load plugins from disk in a way that doesn't involve cloning.

It can be solved by putting plugins in a dedicated 'pack/*/opt' directory (either explicitly or via symlink) and loading them with `:packadd[!]`. But this splits plugin management into two ways, which for some people is very inconvenient.

Supporting this can be useful for several scenarios:
- Plugin is not a Git repo.
- Plugin is under a development by the user. Outside of symlinking, it can be installed via `file://...` source, but it means having to deal with two copies of the plugin. One special subcase of this is contributing to a managed plugin that is currently being used. Which typically involves creating and cloning a fork on Git forge. It usually is cloned in the directory with the same name as the upstream, so it should be possible to load a plugin with the directory name already present in 'pack/core/opt'.

Solution: Update `vim.pack.add()` to load plugins that point to an existing path on disk. In all cases it is assumed that plugin's management (i.e. install/update/delete) is done entirely outside of `vim.pack`, hence the naming of "unmanaged".

---

Resolve #34765

Notes:

- I am not particularly fond of adding this functionality to `vim.pack`. I still think that resolving such cases manually (by explicitly putting or symlinking to a dedicated 'pack/mine/opt' package) is a good enough solution. But I promised to try to resolve this with `vim.pack`, so this is the attempt.

- The term "unmanaged plugin" is the same as [used in 'junegunn/vim-plug'](https://github.com/junegunn/vim-plug/blob/60dd7a5eaf3ec98287e82bc6c2e7f99f31951c04/doc/plug.txt#L154). I think it is more directly shows the intention behind its support. Plus using "local" in Lua code is problematic.

    Plus I think it is more future friendly to have "local plugin" and "unmanaged plugin" be separate things. Maybe something like `version = false` in the future can be used to mark currently managed plugin as unmanaged. Although I personally don't really like the idea of unmanaged plugins in the first place.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
      -- Plugins with local (non-URI) path are loaded but not managed.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -259,6 +267,9 @@ Basic install and management ~
         -- Git branch, tag, or commit hash
         version = 'main',
       },
+
+      -- Plugins with local source are loaded but not managed

comment_regular_data.body:
> Solution: Update `vim.pack.add()` to load plugins that point to an existing path on disk.

@lewis6991 does this address your use-case?

To summarize, `vim.pack.add('/foo')` behaves as "loaded but not managed". So e.g. `pack.get()` won't return the plugin.

> I am not particularly fond of adding this functionality to `vim.pack`. I still think that resolving such cases manually (by explicitly putting or symlinking to a dedicated 'pack/mine/opt' package) is a good enough solution. But I promised to try to resolve this with `vim.pack`, so this is the attempt

Yeah. I don't really see much value in this, but if this PR satisfies #34765 , the cost looks ok. But I wonder what other requirements will pop up...

I think so.

My current manager also allows to update these plugin (by doing `git pull --fast-forward`), so I'l continue using that.

I noticed this will also make creating testcases a bit easier. Currently, you are required to use a custom `XDG_DATA_DIR` to create isolated testcases with `vim.pack`.

> I noticed this will also make creating testcases a bit easier. Currently, you are required to use a custom `XDG_DATA_DIR` to create isolated testcases with `vim.pack`.

If you mean tests for `vim.pack` itself, then it won't as those require managed plugins.

If you mean reproducible examples, then yeah maybe. But for those I'd still recommend using a clean `NVIM_APPNAME`.

> If you mean reproducible examples, then yeah maybe. But for those I'd still recommend using a clean NVIM_APPNAME.

... and `XDG_DATA_DIR` as that is where plugins will be downloaded to.

> > If you mean reproducible examples, then yeah maybe. But for those I'd still recommend using a clean NVIM_APPNAME.
> 
> ... and `XDG_DATA_DIR` as that is where plugins will be downloaded to.

No, `NVIM_APPNAME=nvim-test nvim` is enough. Plugins will be downloaded into '~/.local/share/nvim-test/site/pack/core/opt'.
You do not want that if a testcase requires patches, or general debugging. It's better to isolate all testcase data to a single dir, not somewhere buried in the users XDG dirs which is 7 levels deep.

Could we do the symlink _before_ potentially calling the user defined load function? Currently in this PR, this will not work, and will throw an error

```lua
vim.pack.add({
	{ src = "~/projects/plugins/roslyn.nvim" },
}, {
	load = function(plugin)
		vim.cmd.packadd(plugin.spec.name)
	end,
})
```

Something like this (probably not the best way to do it, but just something I threw together to show the intent), makes the above code not throw an error

```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua
index f518a3db87..5f51f751a1 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/pack.lua
@@ -788,6 +788,16 @@ local function infer_update_details(p)
   p.info.update_details = table.concat(newer_semver_tags, '\n')
 end
 
+local function try_unlink(plug, tmp_plug_path)
+  if not plug.info.managed then
+    -- Adjust 'runtimepath' to contain original path. Don't force using absolute
+    -- path as `:packadd` adds based on `stdpath('data')` (which can be relative).
+    local plug_path_pattern = vim.pesc(tmp_plug_path):gsub('/', '[\\/]')
+    vim.o.runtimepath = vim.o.runtimepath:gsub(plug_path_pattern, plug.path)
+    uv.fs_unlink(tmp_plug_path)
+  end
+end
+
 --- @param plug vim.pack.Plug
 --- @param load boolean|fun(plug_data: {spec: vim.pack.Spec, path: string})
 local function pack_add(plug, load)
@@ -804,18 +814,15 @@ local function pack_add(plug, load)
     unmanaged_plugins[plug.path] = true
   end
 
-  if vim.is_callable(load) then
-    load({ spec = vim.deepcopy(plug.spec), path = plug.path })
-    return
-  end
+  local plug_name = plug.spec.name and plug.spec.name
+    or ('_unmanaged_%d'):format(vim.tbl_count(unmanaged_plugins))
+  plug.spec.name = plug_name
 
-  local plug_name = plug.spec.name
   local tmp_plug_path = ''
   if not plug.info.managed then
     -- Temporarily symlink into main plugin directory to reuse `:packadd` and
     -- have entry order in 'runtimepath' as if it is a managed plugin
     -- Use (hopefully) unique name to avoid conflicts with existing plugins
-    plug_name = '_unmanaged_' .. vim.tbl_count(unmanaged_plugins)
     tmp_plug_path = vim.fs.joinpath(get_plug_dir(), plug_name)
 
     -- Ensure that linking uses absolute path to better work with junction links
@@ -824,16 +831,16 @@ local function pack_add(plug, load)
     uv.fs_symlink(plug.path, vim.fs.abspath(tmp_plug_path), link_opts)
   end
 
+  if vim.is_callable(load) then
+    load({ spec = vim.deepcopy(plug.spec), path = plug.path })
+    try_unlink(plug, tmp_plug_path)
+    return
+  end
+
   -- NOTE: The `:packadd` specifically seems to not handle spaces in dir name
   vim.cmd.packadd({ vim.fn.escape(plug_name, ' '), bang = not load, magic = { file = false } })
 
-  if not plug.info.managed then
-    -- Adjust 'runtimepath' to contain original path. Don't force using absolute
-    -- path as `:packadd` adds based on `stdpath('data')` (which can be relative).
-    local plug_path_pattern = vim.pesc(tmp_plug_path):gsub('/', '[\\/]')
-    vim.o.runtimepath = vim.o.runtimepath:gsub(plug_path_pattern, plug.path)
-    uv.fs_unlink(tmp_plug_path)
-  end
+  try_unlink(plug, tmp_plug_path)
 
   -- The `:packadd` only sources plain 'plugin/' files. Execute 'after/' scripts
   -- if not during startup (when they will be sourced later, even if
```

> Could we do the symlink _before_ potentially calling the user defined load function?

I don't think it is a good idea.

The symlink here is a technical hack to make default loading of unmanaged plugins possible with `:packadd`. This saves a lot of extra code and the result is aligned with how managed plugins are added (like order in 'runtimepath', for example). The symlink is not permanent and is removed right after `:packadd`.

A proper handling of plugins outside of `pack/*/opt` directories is to manually adjust 'runtimepath' and source all necessary scripts. It is doable, but going the `:packadd` route is simpler.

The custom `opts.load` is there specifically to allow full takeover over how loading is done. Performing `:packadd` based on a seemingly random directory (which is outside of `pack/*/opt`) is not a good idea in itself. Also note that symlink is done with some private (hopefully unique) name and exposing that to the `opts.load` is also not clean.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(pack)!: support unmanaged plugins
